awd_titl_txt: NSF INCLUDES DCL: RESET (Re-Enter Stem through Emerging Technology) Conference on Finding Re-Entry Pathways for Women in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF INCLUDES Conference on Finding Re-Entry Pathways for Women in STEM was created in response to the NSF INCLUDES program's Dear Colleague Letter (DCL): Supporting the Re-Entry of Women and Women Veterans in the STEM Workforce through NSF INCLUDES (NSF 19-038). The number of jobs in our country requiring substantial STEM expertise has grown nearly 34 percent over the past decade and employers say they are having trouble filling jobs in occupations that depend on skilled technical workers.  Women and women veterans are a pool of talented individuals who can fill STEM jobs nationwide. The project team is developing, organizing, conducting and evaluating a conference supporting the re-entry of women and women veterans in STEM emerging technology fields, such as cybersecurity, data science, mobile development and cloud computing.  

The goal of the two-day conference is to explore and discuss challenges encountered by returning women with the objective of better understanding their situations and identifying solutions to their problems in accessing emerging technology education and employment.  In addition to the many women students who participate in the conference, there are also presenters and invited participants from industry, NSF INCLUDES Alliances, social science and policy fields, and from support organizations, such as university veteran's affairs and academic services offices at universities. 

An external evaluator, and a conference advisory board, are assessing the outcomes and impacts of this project. Dissemination includes presenting findings at national conferences and publishing in journals, as well as conducting a Webinar on best practices for returning women in emerging technology fields.  Resource materials are published on a project website.  Results from the meeting enhance the understanding of processes for re-entry, and the related barriers and opportunities women face entering and re-entering the STEM workforce, especially in emerging technology fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
In response to the NSF INCLUDES Dear Colleague Letter (DCL) Conference: Supporting the Re-Entry of Women and Women Veterans in the STEM Workforce, Syracuse University in collaboration with Miami Dade College, proposed the RESET (Re-Enter STEM through Emerging Technology) project to provide a platform to share experiential knowledge and evidence-based findings, and to provide recommendations on how the enrollment, retention, recruitment, and employment opportunities of returning women may be improved through different efforts like research, practice, policy, and evaluation. The NSF RESET conference was successful in meeting all 3 of its primary goals since 1) the conference participants reported very high level of satisfaction regarding the conference design and its overall effectiveness in providing a platform for returning women to connect and learn about (re-)entering STEM and emerging technology (EmTech), 2) the studies conducted during this project helped us identify unique barriers and opportunities for minoritized and returning women to (re-)enter EmTech, and 3) the recommendations developed in this project helped inform the community about best practices to create effective re-entry strategies and pathways for returning women to (re-)enter EmTech.

The 2021 NSF RESET Conference, a three-day national virtual conference, was held on March 4-6, 2021. It consisted of 38 sessions and 62 women speakers who presented during the conference. There were 444 women registrants, including 216 student participants, and 2,125 total session views. Due to the demands for millions of EmTech jobs across the industry sectors, it is important to understand the barriers and challenges faced by returning women to (re-)enter EmTech fields. Hence, the NSF INCLUDES DCL RESET Conference concluded with the following outcomes impacting informal and formal STEM/computing/EmTech education research: 

  • Developed a one-stop virtual platform for knowledge dissemination in the community so PI and domain experts can share resources to equip minoritized women for STEM/EmTech education and future-ready workforce.
  • Synthesized the recommendations, opportunities, best practices, and services available especially those regarding re-entry into industry jobs and academic pipeline in EmTech.
  • Generated new knowledge regarding unique challenges and barriers facing returning and minoritized women interested in re-entry into EmTech. The COVID-19 pandemic has brought to sharper light some of the (existing and new) issues and unique challenges that women (re-)entering education and workforce face which are also included in these artifacts.
  • Developed and disseminated resources, artifacts and publications that galvanized industry and academia to better support the re-entry of returning women in future EmTech workforce and education pipeline.
  • Provided opportunity to create and sustain connection among returning women and policy makers, scholars, and industry and academic professionals interested in mentoring on transition to EmTech and STEM in general.
  • Created a new medium for scientific publication for the research community through special issue journal which published research articles in the intersection of EmTech and computing education.
  • Encouraged transformative innovation by informing project related findings through wide-reaching dissemination in scientific communities.
  • Inspired stakeholders from different EmTech fields to look at what has worked well to facilitate re-entry of returning women in various EmTech and STEM careers and replicate, support, and sustain those efforts through a continuous momentum in the community.
  • Followed a collective impact approach to broaden participation and improve diversity in STEM by building capacity with minoritized adult women, which are the untapped talent pool.
  • Developed a potential a pipeline of minoritized women in STEM/EmTech such as AI/ML, cloud computing, data science, cybersecurity, and mobile application. 

While much is known about the challenges of women in commuting and tech fields, there is still much work to be done to understand the unique challenges and barriers one of the largest untapped talent pool, returning women face to transition from career break to STEM workforce. There needs to be collective effort to ensure that returning women can leverage their experiences, technical strengths, and leadership expertise into economic opportunities. As a result of this project, we were able to gather and analyze information about the current state of this topic, identify opportunities to advance this work, and pave the way for greater collaboration among various stakeholders that seek to support the unique needs of returning women. While this work is far from complete, we hope that the resources developed from this conference and the associated study can create a more equitable pathway for returning women to transitions from career break to EmTech workforce.

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2023
Modified by: Farzana Rahman
